Award.AwardTitle: Responses of Root Hydraulic Conductivity to Elevated CO2: Patterns and Mechanisms
Award.AbstractNarration: Rising atmospheric CO2 concentration could have serious consequences for terrestrial ecosystems. These effects are often examined in terms of direct influences on carbon uptake and losses by plants. However, elevated levels of CO2 may result in significant changes in performances of native and crop ecosystems via indirect effects involving uptake and usage of other resources such as water and nutrients. In most native ecosystems, water is the most limiting resource. Therefore, any impact of rising CO2 level on water uptake and usage by vegetation will affect plant and ecosystem productivity as well as affecting the hydrologic biosphere-atmosphere feedbacks. To date, there is some evidence that elevated CO2 may reduce foliage resistance to water loss but considerably less is known about potential changes in other components of water flow within the soil, through the plant and to the atmosphere. The proposed study will examine the effects of projected rise in atmospheric CO2 on a number of forest and crop species. More specifically, effects on root hydraulic conductivity which often constitutes a major barrier to water flow will be examined. Preliminary results along with theoretical considerations indicate that high CO2 may result in a significant change in root uptake and transport capacity of water. The proposed study will also examine the mechanism(s) that may best explain why CO2 would affect root water transport properties. The results will have significant utility for models of plant and ecosystem growth responses to future climates. The study is also designed to determine potential differences in species responses thus providing a mechanistic understanding of CO2 affect on the larger scale ecological processes of biodiversity and population dynamics. Finally, the study will engage K-12 as well as undergraduate students in conceptual and experimental aspects of this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the major challenges of humanity in the 21st century is to better understand the causes and consequences of global climate change. A component of global change that could significantly alter life on earth as well as affecting earth atmosphere exchange of resources is the rising CO2 level.  We now know that elevated levels of atmospheric CO2 affects exchange of water between biosphere and atmosphere, but the mechanistic understanding of how this effect is manifested is poorly understood.  There is growing recognition that at least some of this effect is mediated by partial closure of stomata under high CO2. The exact mechanism of this stomatal closure is currently not clear. The research conducted in this project tested a set of hypotheses that proposed a regulatory role of plant hydraulic properties particularly those of the root system in regulating stomatal responses to high CO2. In this study we examined a wide range of tree species and found that while plant hydraulic traits are important, changes in allometric relationship between root and leaf (uptake/supply and demand) tissues under eCO2 acted as stronger predictor of stomatao responses to high CO2. Furthermore, a new modeling approach revealed that stomatal responses to elevated CO2 would require integration of other physiological parameters whose linkage to plant allometry and hydraulics are not readily apparent. We hope the work presented here underscores the need for the development of a more comprehensive model of stomata and their responses to elevated CO2 by simultaneously considering the coupling of stomata to parameters such as leaf level gas exchange, photosynthetic nitrogen content, allometric adjustments, and changes in hydraulics. An important objective of such integrated model will be to address the broader patterns of commonly observed stomatal decline, but more importantly, to capture the underlying mechanisms responsible for the large species specific variability of this traits under elevated CO2. Ultimately, the findings from this work should have great utility in hydrologic models designed to predict how increased levels of CO2 in the atmosphere may impact biosphere atmosphere exchange of water.
